superresolution

Class LocallyAdaptiveZooming

  • java.lang.Object
    • superresolution.LocallyAdaptiveZooming

  • public class LocallyAdaptiveZooming
extends java.lang.Object
    Class implementing the LAZA algorithm. See: Battiato et al, 2002, A locally adaptive zooming algorithm for digital images.
    Author:
    Tristan

    • Method Detail

      • runLocallyAdaptiveZooming

        public static LayeredMatrix runLocallyAdaptiveZooming(LayeredMatrix m)
                                               throws InvalidRequestException
        Runs the LAZA algorithm on the input image. Note that the version here is slightly modified or, rather, has certain details filled in. When the algorithm asks for x >> y, I require x > y + requiredOffset. Rather than use the color transformation done in the paper, where a simpler algorithm is used for two channels, I just use the basic LAZA on all the channels. The paper says this makes little difference. Note also that the average of the absolute values of the differences are used in place of the 1d greyscale differences used in the paper. Note that LAZA is very fast, including faster than bicubic interpolation, but generally does not look as nice, at least subjectively, especially for colour images.
        Parameters:
        m - Input image
        Returns:
        Throws:
        InvalidRequestException

      • runLocallyAdaptiveZooming

        public static ImageTTAA runLocallyAdaptiveZooming(ImageTTAA m)
                                           throws InvalidRequestException
        Runs the LAZA algorithm on the input image. Note that the version here is slightly modified or, rather, has certain details filled in. When the algorithm asks for x >> y, I require x > y + requiredOffset. Rather than use the color transformation done in the paper, where a simpler algorithm is used for two channels, I just use the basic LAZA on all the channels. The paper says this makes little difference. Note also that the average of the absolute values of the differences are used in place of the 1d greyscale differences used in the paper. Note that LAZA is very fast, including faster than bicubic interpolation, but generally does not look as nice, at least subjectively, especially for colour images.
        Parameters:
        m - Input image
        Returns:
        Throws:
        InvalidRequestException
